question: I tend to aim right without meaning to. How can I fix this while keeping my maps consistent?
answer: You're seeing parallax error, which gets worse as the club gets longer (especially driver). With putter your eyes are over the line so you don’t see it, but with driver you’re off to the side, so square can look left. Set the club to the target first (shaft perpendicular to the target line when you look down), then align your body parallel to the club’s line—face the club, don’t face the target. It will feel way left at first, but that feeling is actually square. Train the routine: balance the club to the target, then match your feet/knees/hips/shoulders parallel to it before looking up.

question: Should I use an alignment stick during rounds to retrain my aim, or just aim more left than I think?
answer: Use an alignment stick in practice. Lay it on your target line and make your feet equidistant from the stick—"face the wall" the stick represents. With longer clubs, stand farther but still face that wall, then set the club and match your body parallel. On the range, set up square and look at the target—you’ll feel crazy left (that’s square). Hit shots a touch right, left, and at the target to calibrate. On course, trust that the left-feeling setup is square and swing.

question: Can you go over landing onto the lead side during transition and how it links with pelvic drop?
answer: Both patterns load the lead side, but the sequence changes ball flight. Rory: upper body starts rotating, pelvis follows, then he drops while continuing to rotate in the same space—pelvis COM migrates forward/left while he stays back-chained, the handle gets deeper, and that supports a draw. Hovland: he begins rotating out earlier as he sets the club to the top, maintains back-chain but gets the ribs more forward, the handle tracks more out, supporting a cut. Both produce lead-side pressure via different ribcage–pelvis timings—choose the one that matches your desired flight.

question: Why should the right hip elevate at the start of the downswing?
answer: It follows gait and spine-engine mechanics. To locomote, the trail hip hikes (lat/glute/oblique shorten) to free the trail foot—same in golf to create space to send the club out on the transverse plane. The pattern is hike-and-bury: backswing (lead hip hikes, trail hip buries) then transition (trail hip hikes, lead hip buries) while the ribs rotate, which keeps the pelvis effectively level and the feet working (heels away, inside ankle bones high). Use a dowel across the ASIS to feel hike–bury while you rotate so the right side elevates as you transition.

question: I’m getting great results using negative alpha from the top through impact in full swing. Should I use the same action in chipping?
answer: No. Negative alpha loads a lot of tissue—great for full-swing speed, overkill for chipping. For chips/pitches, keep the club on a more vertical swing plane (VSSP): up and down with minimal shallow/outward path. Get pressure forward early, control low point/angle of attack, and make an authoritative strike. Think Scheffler: trail wrist extended, face looking down more in the backswing, then the club pitches over to that VSSP and he "cuts" his chips—very stable delivery. Avoid draw-ish shallow patterns for finesse shots.

question: TPI shows good players moving from posterior pelvic tilt to level or anterior at impact. Do you agree, and can you train that?
answer: You can see that pattern, but it’s mostly a byproduct, not a cue. In transition, arms still elevating while you drop produces some spinal extension and apparent anterior tilt. Through the strike, firing the arms out (scapular protraction) puts the spine back into flexion and the pelvis into posterior tilt. Don’t micromanage lumbar flex/extend—your lumbar doesn’t love big ranges. Instead, map good force directions: drop correctly, rotate/ribcage sequence well, and let the tilts emerge from the movement rather than chasing them.

question: In pitching/distance wedge work you emphasize radial loading and release. In a full swing, is there any active trail-wrist dorsiflexion? And aside from tissue loading, how do hand actions differ between full swing and a pitch/distance wedge?
answer: With a neutral grip, radial deviation keeps the face square to your trunk tilt—there’s not much need for active trail-wrist extension unless you also add gamma (face rotation) to keep the leading edge aligned. For short game, feel the face pointing more toward the ground relative to your trunk and check video—the leading edge should track square to your trunk through radial. Release: full swing preference is trail wrist extension-to-flexion and lead wrist flexion-to-extension with minimal supination/pronation—keeps the face square while you turn. In pitching/distance wedges, use more radial to external rotation to keep the club on a vertical swing plane, control low point, and deliver a stable, slightly cutting strike.

question: Can you show progressions to teach the pelvis hike in transition for juniors/novices?
answer: Start with ribcage control seated so the pelvis can’t move: the "boat" drill—oar the water just below the clavicles to alternate left/right lateral bend while shifting the ribcage side to side. Then add pelvis hike–bury standing: hike one side, bury the other while rotating the ribs so the pelvis stays effectively level (avoid lateral shove). Progress to coordinating ribs and pelvis together (spine engine) and finally walk-pattern flows. Visualize the spiral line (print it) to understand how lengthening/shortening drives the shapes you want.

question: How should I position my arms at driver impact? Should the lead elbow face the target, and does it externally rotate?
answer: Keep the arm structure in front of you. Think "steering wheel to 90°," then drop (good spine engine) with that structure leading. The arm action is predominantly internal rotation with the body turning; depending on trajectory, you release earlier (higher) or keep turning longer (flatter). Don’t force a pose like "lead elbow at target"—maintain structure and choose the release timing to match the shot. The apparent external rotation you see is the angular release as the body turns, not a held position.

question: How should the wrists be positioned at impact (thumbs-down?), and how should they move through the follow-through?
answer: Skip "thumbs down." Focus on moving the club dynamically: manage shaft height (tall to level), face openness/closedness, and keep the instrument flowing. Use a drill: stop with the shaft tall, move it 90° through, then hit—no freezing—so you learn to pass through positions rather than pose them. Treat address and finish as the only "positions"; everything else is motion. When you move the club correctly relative to your body, the wrists organize naturally through impact and release.
